events.event_description: U.S. crude oil production reached a record high average of 13.1 million barrels per day in the first eight months of 2024, positioning the United States to be the world's top producer for the seventh consecutive year.
events.citation: In the first eight months of 2024, U.S. crude oil production has averaged a record high of 13.1 million barrels per day (b/d), making it likely the United States will be the world's top producer of crude oil for the seventh consecutive year.

events.event_description: 34 publicly traded U.S. oil companies reported increased well productivity and reduced production costs in Q2 2024, with production reaching 3.9 million b/d, the highest level in five years.
events.citation: Second-quarter 2024 financial results for 34 publicly traded U.S. oil exploration and production (E&P) companies suggest increasing well productivity is helping these companies reduce production costs on a per barrel basis and freeing up cash for other uses such as dividends and share repurchases.

events.event_description: The Permian region showed steady increase in output from newly completed wells over the past two years despite declining active drilling rigs.
events.citation: In the Permian region, the largest source of crude oil production growth in our November Short-Term Energy Outlook forecast, output from newly completed wells has steadily increased over the last two years even as the number of active drilling rigs has declined.

events.event_description: U.S. E&P companies achieved significant cost reduction, with production costs averaging $21/BOE since mid-2022 compared to $32/BOE in 2019, while increasing production by 21%.
events.citation: Upstream capital expenditure per barrel of oil equivalent (BOE) produced has averaged around $21/BOE in real terms since the middle of 2022. Over the same period, crude oil production by the E&P companies increased by 21%. By comparison, these E&P companies produced crude oil at an average production cost of $32/BOE in 2019.
